awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   Multiscale Study of Active Cellular Matter: Simulation, Modeling, and Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
Active cellular matter is the basis of novel synthetic active fluids made of mixtures of suspended cytoskeletal filaments and molecular motors. By consuming chemical fuel, the molecular motors (e.g., kinesins) can bind to and create actively moving crosslinks between the biofilaments (e.g., microtubules) to drive their relative motion, which leads to large-scale collective motions in the filament/motor mixture through hydrodynamic coupling. Synthetic active suspensions made of small numbers of components reveal how higher-order aspects of assembly and organization are built in living cells. These systems also present new challenges to our understanding, design, and analysis of materials, and have the potential to provide valuable new technologies such as autonomously moving and self-healing materials.

In this work, the investigators study active cellular matter composed of microtubules and molecular motors through multiscale methods, and tightly coupled modeling, analysis, and simulation. The project aims to understand the fundamental interactions underlying stress generation within bundles of rigid/flexible biofilaments that undergo dynamic instability, as well as the nonlinear dynamics and hierarchical pattern formation in large-scale collective motions. The project will also predict key material properties including its coherent structures, local heterogeneity, time- and length-scales, and material rheology. To resolve the physics at different length- and time-scales, several methods will be developed and integrated: (1) microtubule-motor interactions will be simulated using a kinetic Monte Carlo method; (2) the hydrodynamic interactions between objects of various shapes will be modeled using a nonlocal slender body/boundary integral method, together with fast summation methods; (3) a pseudo-spectral method will be implemented to simulate the collective motion through a continuous active liquid-crystal type model.

por.por_cntn:
This project supported the development of multiscale modeling approaches to study active cellular matter composed of protein filaments such as microtubules or f-actin and ATP-fueled motor proteins such as kinesin or dynein. Such active cytoskeletal assemblies are responsible for a wide variety of essential cellular functions in living cells, including mitosis, cytokinesis, and cell mobility, and are also the building blocks for novel synthetic active fluids outside the cell.

The dynamics of active cellular matter is inherently stochastic, due to the random thermal motion of the constituent biomolecules and to the stochastic nature of the chemical reactions and bimolecular binding and unbinding events that maintain cytoskeletal active matter in far-from-equilibrium states. To model the microscopic behavior of these materials, we have previously developed nonequilibrium statistical mechanical methods that incorporate the key physical mechanisms responsible for their activity. This project built on this prior work, leading to the creation of more efficient, multiscale simulation methods, and advancing our understanding of active cellular matter through the modeling of in vivo and in vitro systems.

Among the simplest active systems with complex dynamics are suspensions of immotile "extensor" particles that exert active extensile dipolar stresses on the fluid in which they are immersed. We have analyzed extensor suspensions within a Doi-Onsager kinetic theory based on microscopic modeling, yielding complex flows and disclination dynamics very similar to phenomenological Landau-deGennes Q-tensor theories. The quasi-equilibrium Bingham closure was used to develop a nonstandard Q-tensor theory (B Q-tensor theory) that resolves the suspension's dynamics at a far reduced computational cost, and this theory was applied to study the dynamics of extensor suspensions in circular and biconcave domains.

A prototypical example of cytoskeletal remodeling is mitotic spindle assembly, during which microtubules nucleate, undergo dynamic instability, bundle, and organize into a bipolar spindle. Key mechanisms of this process include regulated filament polymerization, cross-linking, and motor-protein activity. Remarkably, using passive cross-linkers, fission yeast can assemble a bipolar spindle in the absence of motor proteins. We developed a predictive torque-balance model for spindle assembly dynamics in systems of dynamic microtubule bundles, spindle-pole bodies localized to the nuclear envelope, and passive cross-linkers, and compared these results with those obtained from kinetic Monte Carlo-Brownian dynamics simulations, which include cross-linker binding kinetics and other stochastic effects. Our results show that rapid cross-linker redistribution to microtubule overlaps facilitates cross-linker-driven spindle assembly, a testable prediction for future experiments. The combination of these two modeling techniques forms the basis for a general method for studying cytoskeletal network reorganization.

The essential functions required for mitotic spindle assembly and chromosome biorientation and segregation are not fully understood, despite extensive study. To illuminate the combinations of ingredients most important to align and segregate chromosomes and simultaneously assemble a bipolar spindle, we developed a computational model of fission-yeast mitosis. Robust chromosome biorientation requires progressive restriction of attachment geometry, destabilization of misaligned attachments, and attachment force dependence. Large spindle length fluctuations can occur when the kinetochore-microtubule attachment lifetime is long. The primary spindle force generators are kinesin-5 motors and crosslinkers in early mitosis, while interkinetochore stretch becomes important after biorientation. The same mechanisms that contribute to persistent biorientation lead to segregation of chromosomes to the poles after anaphase onset. This model therefore provides a framework to interrogate key requirements for robust chromosome biorientation, spindle length regulation, and force generation in the spindle.

This project has contributed to the statistical physics of far from-equilibrium soft matter, and to its potential for the creation of transformative new approaches to the design of active materials. The PIs have been active in communicating their research findings to a broad and diverse audience through departmental colloquia, seminars, and conference presentations. This research activity also informs curriculum development, including for two courses taught recently at CU Boulder by the PI (Graduate Statistical Physics, Graduate Computational Statistical Physics). The PIs provide research opportunities for undergraduates through local REU programs and programs to enhance the participation of members of underrepresented groups in scientific research. Currently, one female undergraduate is a member of the CU Computational Biophysics group.
